Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: The First Ever Demographic Study of Solar Physics, Space Physics, and Upper Atmospheric Physics
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will conduct the first comprehensive demographic study of solar and space physics and related scientific disciplines. This includes scientists who investigate: 1) the Sun; 2) the nature of the region of space affected by our sun; and 3) the response of Earth and the rest of our solar system to this space environment. The disciplinary areas in which these scientists operate include: solar physics, space physics, magnetospheric physics, aeronomy, and upper atmospheric physics. The project is a collaboration between the co-chairs of the Education & Workforce working group associated with the ongoing National Research Council (NRC) Decadal Survey in Solar and Space Physics with the American Institute of Physics (AIP). The objective of the project is to assess the demographic health of these tightly coupled areas of scientific endeavor.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main components of this research were:  1) a National Demographic Survey of professionals in the solar and space physics field; and 2) a Pathways Study of graduate students to identify factors that lead college undergraduates to do graduate work in solar or space physics. The research helped to inform the development of a 10-year strategic plan for solar and space physics.

This work is significant because:  1) there had been no prior demographic study of this scientific domain;  2) the professionals being studied are the stewards of millions of dollars in federal funding;  and 3) the field being studied is highly relevant to society.  The field informs how solar storms affect vital space-based and ground-based assets (e.g. power grids, communication, weather & navigation satellites), and how variations in the Sun’s output relate to other important issues such as ozone depletion and climate change.

This project collaborated with the American Institute of Physics (AIP), the National Science Foundation (NSF), and multiple professional societies to compile the most complete data base of solar and space physics professionals to date.  This in itself was a rather large challenge because practitioners in solar and space physics are trained in many areas of science (from math to physics to astrophysics to chemistry to atmospheric science to computer science to engineering), and they work in a variety of academic departments and types of institutions (government labs, non-profit organizations, industries, and universities).

The National Demographic Survey developed and distributed to this data base now offers a valuable starting point for future surveys. The Survey generated a wealth of quantitative data, and a few open-ended questions resulted in more than 100 pages of written responses. Some findings are highlighted below:

1. Of the 1000+ respondents, 83% were men and 17% women. Most were white (81%), 13% were Asian or Asian American, with 6% other.  

2. The median age of the respondents was 51 years old with a symmetric distribution (the middle 50% were between 40 and 62 years old).

3. Physics was by far the most common undergraduate degree (62%).

4. For those earning their PhDs in 1999 or earlier, Physics was the most common degree field (40%). For those earning PhDs since 2000 the most common was Space Physics (36%), while Physics dropped to 27%.

5. Almost three-quarters of graduate student support and two-thirds of undergraduate student research support is from NASA or NSF.

6. Nearly three-quarters of recent PhD recipients (receiving their degree since 2000) participated in some form of undergraduate research.

7. About half of the respondents reported that they were involved at some level in K-12 education and/or public outreach.

8. One open-ended question asked 'What have been the barriers to your career up until this point?' Over 31% (48 of 154) of the written responses from women indicated some form of gender discrimination or lack of family friendly policies as barriers to their career.

9. Responses to other open ended questions suggested that respondents were generally optimistic about the abilities of the next generation, but pessimistic about reduction in funding and NASA missions.
